metadata.title: How to overcome Coder’s Block. When you’re scared of your console | by Ari Joury, PhD | Towards Data Science
metadata.description: Have you ever felt completely blocked? Have you ever been staring at your blank screen for hours, unable to jot anything down? Welcome to the club. You’re pouring over your computer science…

all_paragraphs: Have you ever felt completely blocked? Have you ever been staring at your blank screen for hours, unable to jot anything down? Welcome to the club.

You’re pouring over your computer science assignment as I enter the room. Your desk is covered in scripts and term sheets. Your computer screen is a big black void except for the little white pointer that is blinking in the upper left corner. The whole room seems to be screaming out your desperation.
‘No — this assignment from my computer science class is driving me nuts. It’s due tomorrow and I haven’t even coded a single line!’
‘How long have you been working on it now?’
‘Okay, time to take a break. Do you want a cup of tea?’
‘You can get back to your assignment after that.’
You follow me downstairs and I flip the kettle on. Once our tea is poured, we go back up to your room.
‘It’s just — I understand nothing. I’m sitting there, thinking and thinking, and I just can’t do it.’
‘What’s the problem? Do you understand what you’re expected to do?’
‘In principle, yes. But I don’t have a clue how to tell the computer what it’s supposed to do. How do I even begin with this?’

‘It’s like writer’s block. Sometimes when you write, you’ll be sitting in front of a blank sheet of paper for hours, unable to jot down a single word. At some point, you get scared of the piece of paper because you’ve looked at it for so long.
‘And the same happens with coder’s block. You stare at your console, unable to do anything, until the console scares you.’
A complex piece of code is made of lots of simple subroutines
‘Let’s take it step by step. We’ll begin by writing a Hello-World-program.’
‘But that’s easy, we did that five weeks ago!’
‘That’s exactly the reason why we’re doing it again. It’s simple, so you won’t get blocked.’
You open a new text file.
‘Do I have to include some package before printing the Hello-World-message?’
‘You sure do. What kind of object is the Hello-World-message?’
‘A string? Ah, wait! I need to include the string package… Okay, got it.’
‘Alright, now type the message and execute.’
‘Great! In your assignment you also have to print something on the screen. How about writing that part first?’
‘We’ll do it step by step. What do you need to print?’
‘The values of some variables. But I haven’t calculated them yet. So how can I print them?’
‘You can put in dummy values for now. Just make sure you leave a comment to mark the dummies. This way we’ll remember to replace them by the real value later on.’
‘Let’s check! Execute the program, please.
‘Whoops, the output isn’t as we’d expected. Let’s fix the bugs.’
‘But I can’t see anything wrong in the code!’
‘You did a little typo over there…’
‘Oh damnit! Okay, now it’s working correctly.’
‘Awesome! Now what else do we need to do?’
‘Calculate the value of the variables.’
Half an hour later, the program is up and running.
Never forget to do test runs and debug
‘Wow, thank you! You saved my life.’
‘Well, basically you wrote the code all by yourself. I just gave you some guidance. You can delete the Hello-World-program, by the way.’
‘Oh, sure, I forgot about that part. But seriously — I was sitting there for hours. Then you come in and it’s solved in a few minutes. You’re a genius!’
‘Well, spending hours over a problem is often not the way to go.

‘When I started coding, I was often too shy to ask people for help because I thought I’d seem stupid. So I’d be sitting in front of my screen for hours, unable to solve the problem, getting more and more anxious about it.
‘When I finally went and asked for help, the issue usually turned out to be a little typo or another minor mistake.’
‘So that taught you to ask for help when you’re stuck?’
‘Yes, you should always ask for help. And don’t wait for hours before asking. Try to figure out the problem in a reasonable time. And if that time has passed without a lot of progress, ask.’
‘In my case, I’d figured out the problem but I couldn’t tell the computer what to do.’

‘In that case, do something stupid. Nothing completely senseless, but something very simple — like a Hello-World-program. You know how to make a computer do things. But a certain level of complexity can be quite intimidating at the start.
‘You can use this simple code to build your program up. Start with the easiest part, then move on to the harder ones.’
‘So the next time I don’t know how to start, I’ll do something really simple — even if it seems unrelated to the task at hand. And then do the simplest parts of my task first.’

‘Exactly. And if you’ve thought about the problem for hours before writing any code, take a break! Get a cup of tea or coffee, or go for a quick walk. After all, it’s unlikely that you’re going to be productive after hours of coder’s block.’
‘Oh man, I think I need to put all that on a poster. Thank you so much!’
‘You’re welcome! Let me know if you have problems with your next assignment.’
